pullRequest.body:
Establish a principle of isolated zeros and show that the set where a meromorphic function has infinite order is clopen in the domain of meromorphy.

These theorems are used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [ef1659a974](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21083/commits/ef1659a9749460e30a5f695db0ea2e23110de9b9)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ MeromorphicAt.eventually_eq_zero_or_eventually_ne_zero`
`+ exists_order_ne_top_iff_forall`
`+ order_ne_top_of_isPreconnected`
`++ isClopen_setOf_order_eq_top`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Thanks again! Writing the code, I was totally unaware of the `filter_upwards` tactic [which David Loeffler showed me only very recently]. I will follow your suggestion, come back to you, and make sure to consistently use it in the future.
I implemented your suggestions. I tried to see if `filter_upwards` could be used to streamline the proof of `clopen_of_order_eq_top`, but with no success…
@sgouezel Thanks. I implemented your suggestion(s), expanded non-terminal `simp`s, and added an analog of `isClopen_setOf_order_eq_top` for analytic functions, as requested.

The theorems on `isClopen` are nice, but I am not sure they are the most usable versions. Do you think you could add a consequence assuming that `U` is preconnected, that `x` and `y` belong to `U` and that the order at `x` is top, and saying that the order at `y` is top?

@sgouezel The theorem you are asking is already written down and used extensively in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD). It was not included here because I wanted to keep the size of the PR small. I will add it and come back to you. Thanks again, Stefan.

@sgouezel I added the theorems that you requested. I allowed myself to formulate them with "…has finite order" instead of "…has infinite order" because this is what I use in the applications. Thanks again.
Thanks for adding the new lemma! I just have a minor comment on a useless completeness assumption.
Thanks for adding the new lemma! I just have a minor comment on a useless completeness assumption.

Here is a suggestion for a more streamlined proof:
```
  obtain ⟨n, h⟩ := hf
  rcases h.eventually_eq_zero_or_eventually_ne_zero with h₁ | h₂
  · left
    filter_upwards [nhdsWithin_le_nhds h₁, self_mem_nhdsWithin] with x hx h'x
    simp only [Set.mem_compl_iff, Set.mem_singleton_iff] at h'x
    simpa [sub_eq_zero, h'x] using hx
  · right
    filter_upwards [h₂, self_mem_nhdsWithin] with x hx h'x
    simp only [Set.mem_compl_iff, Set.mem_singleton_iff] at h'x
    simpa [sub_eq_zero, h'x] using hx
```
What you're doing is moving away from the filters. Instead, you should try to use them fully, because this is extremely convenient.
Roger. I followed your advice and simplified the proof quite dramatically.

You should avoid nonterminal simps, i.e., bare `simp` like you are doing here, in the middle of the proof: if someone changes the simpset (the set of lemmas that simp appplies) in another file, then your proof could break because the state after the `simp` would change. Instead, use `simp only`, with the right set of lemmas, so that it is more robust. To do that, use `simp?` to see which lemmas your simp call uses.

Same thing below.
Done.

```suggestion
theorem isClopen_setOf_order_eq_top {U : Set 𝕜} [CompleteSpace E] (h₁f : MeromorphicOn f U) :
```
Do we have this theorem for holomorphic functions, by the way? It would be strange to have it in the meromorphic case but not the holomorphic case...

```suggestion
theorem isClopen_setOf_order_eq_top (h₁f : AnalyticOnNhd 𝕜 f U) :
    IsClopen { u : U | (h₁f u.1 u.2).order = ⊤ } := by
  constructor
  · rw [← isOpen_compl_iff, isOpen_iff_forall_mem_open]
    intro z hz
    rcases (h₁f z.1 z.2).eventually_eq_zero_or_eventually_ne_zero with h | h
    · -- Case: f is locally zero in a punctured neighborhood of z
      rw [← (h₁f z.1 z.2).order_eq_top_iff] at h
      tauto
    · -- Case: f is locally nonzero in a punctured neighborhood of z
      obtain ⟨t', h₁t', h₂t', h₃t'⟩ := eventually_nhds_iff.1 (eventually_nhdsWithin_iff.1 h)
      use Subtype.val ⁻¹' t'
      constructor
      · intro w hw
        simp only [mem_compl_iff, mem_setOf_eq]
        by_cases h₁w : w = z
        · rwa [h₁w]
        · rw [(h₁f _ w.2).order_eq_zero_iff.2 ((h₁t' w hw) (Subtype.coe_ne_coe.mpr h₁w))]
          exact ENat.zero_ne_top
```
You shouldn't need completeness of the target space here.
ditto, completeness is probably not necessary.
Better spell it with `{x y : 𝕜} (hx : x ∈ U) (hy : y ∈ U)`, because it's the shape the assumptions or conclusions will have most of the time
Done

```suggestion
theorem exists_order_ne_top_iff_forall {U : Set 𝕜} [CompleteSpace E]
```
I'd drop the end of the lemma name, because what else could it be?

```suggestion
theorem order_ne_top_of_isPreconnected {U : Set 𝕜} [CompleteSpace E] {x y : U}
```
I'd single out the important assumption in the lemma name.

pullRequest.title: feat: principle of isolated zeros for meromorphic functions
